segment.tokens: Well this chap uses these gills for the same purpose "
as the steamer uses its screw to scull through the water
After the nymph has its full growth
" some sunny morning soon after daylight it makes its way up of the water on to a stem to split
it waits quietly for the old dark skin
Then out crawls a soft-skinned creature with gauzy wings
it has to wait awhile for the warm sunshine to harden the skin and strengthen the muscle
the new dragon-fly with its glistening body flies out from the pond in the bright , warm light "
" No it dies after twenty-five to forty-five days of its flight
Finally Betty lent him her broad hat
Finally Betty at last Jack caught the insect
" They are made up of thousands of facets
( a facet is just a small plain )
as many as thirty thousand facets in one eye
nothing escapes the sight of this hawk of the air
Look at the wings on this fellow
look at the picture I drew for you of the nymph
I drew for you of the nymph
Well this fellow wings begin in the nymph as tiny sacs , or pads , made by the pushing out of the wall of the body
made the pushing of the wall of the body
Running all through between the two layers of the wing are thickened lines of chitin
In the new wing , protected by these thickenings , are air-tubes
air-tubes divide into all parts of the wing
as the wing reaches its full growth
But most of the air-tubes die "
" We are talking too much fishing too little
And up up the brook they went
VII THE SWIMMING-POOL Two three days after the fishing expedition the boys had gathered together at the swimming-pool , Ben Gile with them
the boys had gathered together at the swimming-pool , Ben Gile with them
a minute before you go into the water
It wo n't do to bathe
round on the stones under the water
sponges grew in these parts at all
" Oh yes there are many of them in the ponds "
He was hiding carefully under that stone keeping of the way of the dragon-fly nymph , who would so gladly gobble him up "
the dragon-fly nymph would so gladly gobble him up
than that dragon-fly nymph you drew a picture of
See here on each side of its body are these fine little moving moving moving as possible out of the water
so that they may get as much fresh air
within these are the fine of the air-tubes
" Do n't they breathe just the way "
" No throughout the body of an insect is a of tiny white tubes
Some day we 'll look at these tubes under the microscope
From end to end of the tube is a fine of chitin
twisted in a close spiral like a spring
The coiled thread holds the little tube open
so that the air may pass readily
But your little fellow Jack can not have pores on the sides of the body like the last nymph
the water would get into its tubes
He wished to begin the swim
probably he would not have been so
